payload.instructions:
# Agent Instructions

- At the start of each new conversation, open and summarize `NEXT_STEPS.md` before taking any action.


## Skills
These skills are discovered at startup from multiple local sources. Each entry includes a name, description, and file path so you can open the source for full instructions.
- skill-creator: Guide for creating effective skills. This skill should be used when users want to create a new skill (or update an existing skill) that extends Codex's capabilities with specialized knowledge, workflows, or tool integrations. (file: /home/deck/.codex/skills/.system/skill-creator/SKILL.md)
- skill-installer: Install Codex skills into $CODEX_HOME/skills from a curated list or a GitHub repo path. Use when a user asks to list installable skills, install a curated skill, or install a skill from another repo (including private repos). (file: /home/deck/.codex/skills/.system/skill-installer/SKILL.md)
- Discovery: Available skills are listed in project docs and may also appear in a runtime "## Skills" section (name + description + file path). These are the sources of truth; skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  3) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  4) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Description as trigger: The YAML `description` in `SKILL.md` is the primary trigger signal; rely on it to decide applicability. If unsure, ask a brief clarification before proceeding.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deeply nested references; prefer one-hop files explicitly linked from `SKILL.md`.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

# AGENTS.md instructions for /home/deck

<INSTRUCTIONS>
# Agent Instructions

- At the start of each new conversation, open and summarize `NEXT_STEPS.md` before taking any action.


## Skills
These skills are discovered at startup from multiple local sources. Each entry includes a name, description, and file path so you can open the source for full instructions.
- skill-creator: Guide for creating effective skills. This skill should be used when users want to create a new skill (or update an existing skill) that extends Codex's capabilities with specialized knowledge, workflows, or tool integrations. (file: /home/deck/.codex/skills/.system/skill-creator/SKILL.md)
- skill-installer: Install Codex skills into $CODEX_HOME/skills from a curated list or a GitHub repo path. Use when a user asks to list installable skills, install a curated skill, or install a skill from another repo (including private repos). (file: /home/deck/.codex/skills/.system/skill-installer/SKILL.md)
- Discovery: Available skills are listed in project docs and may also appear in a runtime "## Skills" section (name + description + file path). These are the sources of truth; skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  3) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  4) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Description as trigger: The YAML `description` in `SKILL.md` is the primary trigger signal; rely on it to decide applicability. If unsure, ask a brief clarification before proceeding.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deeply nested references; prefer one-hop files explicitly linked from `SKILL.md`.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.
</INSTRUCTIONS>

# Next Steps

## Current state
- GitHub Actions/VHS workflow added; pushes work when DNS resolves `github.com`.
- Local Actions runner uses `act` via Makefile, but installation failed because DNS could not resolve `github.com`.
- `.actrc` added with default platform mapping for `act`.
- Latest commits are local and not pushed due to intermittent DNS failures.

## What to do next
1) Restore DNS/network so `github.com` resolves.
2) Run:
   - `make actions-install`
   - `make actions-list`
   - `make actions-test`
   - `make actions-vhs`
3) Push: `git push -u origin main`

## Notes
- If `act` install succeeds, the Makefile targets should work as-is.
- The VHS workflow will generate `assets/archlinux-kde.gif` and auto-commit it via GitHub Actions.

*** Begin Patch
*** Update File: /home/deck/NEXT_STEPS.md
@@
 ## Current state
-- GitHub Actions/VHS workflow added; pushes work when DNS resolves `github.com`.
-- Local Actions runner uses `act` via Makefile, but installation failed because DNS could not resolve `github.com`.
-- `.actrc` added with default platform mapping for `act`.
-- Latest commits are local and not pushed due to intermittent DNS failures.
+- GitHub Actions/VHS workflow added; `.actrc` maps `ubuntu-latest`.
+- `act` installed to `/home/deck/.local/bin/act`.
+- `make actions-list` and `make actions-test` completed successfully.
+- `make actions-vhs` failed during checkout: `no space left on device` writing to `/tmp`.
+- `git push` to `origin main` succeeded.
 
 ## What to do next
-1) Restore DNS/network so `github.com` resolves.
-2) Run:
-   - `make actions-install`
-   - `make actions-list`
-   - `make actions-test`
-   - `make actions-vhs`
-3) Push: `git push -u origin main`
+1) Free disk space (especially `/tmp`/Docker): remove unused images/containers or clean temp files.
+2) Re-run `make actions-vhs`.
+3) If the GIF was generated/committed locally, check `git status` and push if needed.
 
 ## Notes
-- If `act` install succeeds, the Makefile targets should work as-is.
 - The VHS workflow will generate `assets/archlinux-kde.gif` and auto-commit it via GitHub Actions.
*** End Patch

DISCOVERY_STORAGES_PATH ?= $(DISCOVERY_OUTPUT_DIR)/DISCOVERY_STORAGES.md
DISCOVERY_ISOS_PATH ?= $(DISCOVERY_OUTPUT_DIR)/DISCOVERY_ISOS.md
DISCOVERY_VMS_PORTS_PATH ?= $(DISCOVERY_OUTPUT_DIR)/DISCOVERY_VMS_PORTS.md
DISCOVERY_VMS_SCREENSHOTS_PATH ?= $(DISCOVERY_OUTPUT_DIR)/DISCOVERY_VMS_SCREENSHOTS.md

.PHONY: actions-install actions-list actions-test actions-vhs actions-run actions-discovery submodules discovery-full

submodules:
	git submodule update --init --recursive

actions-install:
	./scripts/install-act.sh

actions-list:
	$(ACT) -l

actions-test: submodules
	$(ACT) -n -W .github/workflows/vhs.yml $(ACT_PLATFORMS) $(ACT_FLAGS)

actions-vhs: submodules
	$(ACT) -W .github/workflows/vhs.yml -j record $(ACT_PLATFORMS) $(ACT_FLAGS)

actions-discovery: submodules
	$(ACT) -W .github/workflows/thinkpadkali1dotfiles-discovery.yml -j record $(ACT_PLATFORMS) $(ACT_FLAGS)

discovery-full: submodules
	@mkdir -p "$(DISCOVERY_OUTPUT_DIR)" "$(SCREENSHOT_DIR)"
	DISCOVERY_VMS_PATH="$(DISCOVERY_VMS_PATH)" ./thinkpadkali1dotfiles/scripts/check_hosts.sh
	DISCOVERY_STORAGES_PATH="$(DISCOVERY_STORAGES_PATH)" ./thinkpadkali1dotfiles/scripts/discover_storages.sh
	DISCOVERY_ISOS_PATH="$(DISCOVERY_ISOS_PATH)" ./thinkpadkali1dotfiles/scripts/discover_isos.sh
	DISCOVERY_VMS_PORTS_PATH="$(DISCOVERY_VMS_PORTS_PATH)" ./thinkpadkali1dotfiles/scripts/discover_vm_ports.sh
	SCREENSHOT_DIR="$(SCREENSHOT_DIR)" DISCOVERY_VMS_SCREENSHOTS_PATH="$(DISCOVERY_VMS_SCREENSHOTS_PATH)" ./thinkpadkali1dotfiles/scripts/capture_vm_screenshots.sh

actions-run: actions-vhs

payload.text:
**Optimizing disk space and cleanup**

I'm planning to help free up space by pruning dangling images and running `docker system prune -f` to clear unused networks and containers safely. I want to check for large files in `/tmp` too, since act might leave big temporary files, to better understand where space can be reclaimed. I'm cautious about removing images or containers in use but given the user's request for cleanup, I'll carefully proceed while keeping them informed.

summary.text:
**Optimizing disk space and cleanup**

I'm planning to help free up space by pruning dangling images and running `docker system prune -f` to clear unused networks and containers safely. I want to check for large files in `/tmp` too, since act might leave big temporary files, to better understand where space can be reclaimed. I'm cautious about removing images or containers in use but given the user's request for cleanup, I'll carefully proceed while keeping them informed.

payload.text:
**Proposing disk cleanup options**

I freed 1.6GB and verified /tmp space is still okay. Next, I plan to suggest using --bind to avoid copying to /tmp, since the failure was due to repo size. I'll offer options like running `make actions-vhs ACT_FLAGS=--bind`, moving the repo to a smaller directory, or setting `ACT_FLAGS=--artifact-server-path`. I'll also mention cleaning unused Docker images to free more space and note the root partition is small, so deleting large files there could help. I'll provide clear step suggestions without asking for approval.

summary.text:
**Proposing disk cleanup options**

I freed 1.6GB and verified /tmp space is still okay. Next, I plan to suggest using --bind to avoid copying to /tmp, since the failure was due to repo size. I'll offer options like running `make actions-vhs ACT_FLAGS=--bind`, moving the repo to a smaller directory, or setting `ACT_FLAGS=--artifact-server-path`. I'll also mention cleaning unused Docker images to free more space and note the root partition is small, so deleting large files there could help. I'll provide clear step suggestions without asking for approval.

payload.message:
Freed space by pruning dangling Docker images (reclaimed ~1.6GB) and verified `/tmp` is small. The failure isn‚Äôt really from ‚Äúlow disk‚Äù in `/tmp`; it‚Äôs because `act` is trying to copy the entire `/home/deck` workspace (hundreds of GB) into `/tmp`, which will always fail.

Best fix: run `act` with bind-mounting so it doesn‚Äôt copy the workspace.

If you want me to proceed, I can:
1) Run `make actions-vhs ACT_FLAGS=--bind` to avoid the `/tmp` copy.
2) Remove larger unused images (e.g., `dpg4x`, `debian:bookworm-slim`, or even `ghcr.io/catthehacker/ubuntu:act-latest`) to free more space.

Best fix: run `act` with bind-mounting so it doesn‚Äôt copy the workspace.

If you want me to proceed, I can:
1) Run `make actions-vhs ACT_FLAGS=--bind` to avoid the `/tmp` copy.
2) Remove larger unused images (e.g., `dpg4x`, `debian:bookworm-slim`, or even `ghcr.io/catthehacker/ubuntu:act-latest`) to free more space.

payload.text:
**Investigating large build context issue**

I'm noticing the build context for the Docker action is huge‚Äîabout 55GB‚Äîlikely because act is using the entire home directory as context. I'm thinking I'll check the workflow and Dockerfile paths to see how context is defined and then suggest adding a .dockerignore or adjusting the context to avoid transferring unnecessary files. It also seems wise to inform the user that the workflow run is still ongoing but timed out while transferring context and offer to stop and retry with a smaller build context.

name: VHS

on:

  workflow_dispatch:

jobs:
  record:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - name: Checkout
        uses: actions/checkout@v4

      - name: Set up Buildx
        uses: docker/setup-buildx-action@v3

      - name: Build Arch Linux KDE image (cached)
        uses: docker/build-push-action@v5
        with:
          context: .
          file: Dockerfile.archlinux
          load: true
          tags: deck0:ci
          cache-from: type=gha
          cache-to: type=gha,mode=max

      - name: Record demo with VHS
        uses: charmbracelet/vhs-action@v2
        with:
          tape: .github/vhs/archlinux-kde.tape

      - name: Commit updated GIF
        uses: stefanzweifel/git-auto-commit-action@v5
        with:
          commit_message: "Update VHS recording"
          file_pattern: assets/archlinux-kde.gif

RUN pacman -Syu --noconfirm \

        konsole \

USER deck
WORKDIR /home/deck/deck0_dotfiles

payload.text:
**Optimizing Docker build context**

I'm reviewing how the Dockerfile‚Äôs COPY command pulls the entire huge repo, which seems to include the whole home directory. To reduce build context size, I‚Äôm considering adding a .dockerignore that excludes bulky directories, keeping only essential folders like .github/vhs, README, assets, and maybe scripts. This way, the COPY . step still works but includes minimal necessary files, making the image smaller and the build more efficient. I'll also check what the VHS tape actually uses to confirm what‚Äôs needed.

payload.text:
**Managing Docker build context and container stops**

I'm sorting out how to drastically reduce the Docker build context by crafting a minimal .dockerignore that only allows essential files and directories, preventing huge transfers during builds. Since the current build timed out due to massive context, I'll stop the active containers to free resources before adding the .dockerignore and then plan to rerun the build with a longer timeout.

payload.text:
**Analyzing ffmpeg install failure in workflow**

I‚Äôm investigating why the ffmpeg install fails during the VHS action, suspecting it‚Äôs due to missing or unauthenticated GitHub token causing rate limits or network issues in the `act` environment. I‚Äôm considering workarounds like preinstalling ffmpeg via apt into the runner tool cache so the action‚Äôs check finds it cached, setting appropriate environment variables, and patching the workflow to add this step before VHS runs. This should help avoid failed downloads and make local runs smoother.

summary.text:
**Analyzing ffmpeg install failure in workflow**

I‚Äôm investigating why the ffmpeg install fails during the VHS action, suspecting it‚Äôs due to missing or unauthenticated GitHub token causing rate limits or network issues in the `act` environment. I‚Äôm considering workarounds like preinstalling ffmpeg via apt into the runner tool cache so the action‚Äôs check finds it cached, setting appropriate environment variables, and patching the workflow to add this step before VHS runs. This should help avoid failed downloads and make local runs smoother.

payload.name: apply_patch
payload.input:
*** Begin Patch
*** Update File: /home/deck/.github/workflows/vhs.yml
@@
       - name: Build Arch Linux KDE image (cached)
         uses: docker/build-push-action@v5
         with:
           context: .
           file: Dockerfile.archlinux
           load: true
           tags: deck0:ci
           cache-from: type=gha
           cache-to: type=gha,mode=max
 
+      - name: Seed ffmpeg cache for vhs-action
+        run: |
+          sudo apt-get update
+          sudo apt-get install -y ffmpeg
+          cache_dir="${RUNNER_TOOL_CACHE:-/opt/hostedtoolcache}"
+          mkdir -p "${cache_dir}/ffmpeg/latest/x64/bin"
+          ln -sf "$(command -v ffmpeg)" "${cache_dir}/ffmpeg/latest/x64/bin/ffmpeg"
+
       - name: Record demo with VHS
         uses: charmbracelet/vhs-action@v2
         with:
           tape: .github/vhs/archlinux-kde.tape
*** End Patch

*** Begin Patch
*** Update File: /home/deck/.github/workflows/vhs.yml
@@
       - name: Seed ffmpeg cache for vhs-action
         run: |
           sudo apt-get update
           sudo apt-get install -y ffmpeg
           cache_dir="${RUNNER_TOOL_CACHE:-/opt/hostedtoolcache}"
           mkdir -p "${cache_dir}/ffmpeg/latest/x64/bin"
           ln -sf "$(command -v ffmpeg)" "${cache_dir}/ffmpeg/latest/x64/bin/ffmpeg"
+          touch "${cache_dir}/ffmpeg/latest/x64.complete"
*** End Patch

payload.text:
**Investigating tool-cache version matching issues**

I'm figuring out why the tool-cache `find` method can't locate ffmpeg when using 'latest' as the version; it seems the version string 'latest' isn't treated as a valid semver, causing `find` to fail, and I'm considering workarounds like using a semver instead, skipping the install, or adjusting tokens or inputs to bypass the issue.

*** End Patch

payload.message:
Got the build context under control with a new `.dockerignore`, and updated the workflow to seed ffmpeg plus set the tool-cache envs, but `act` still fails in `charmbracelet/vhs-action` with `Failed to install ffmpeg`. The action tries to pull ffmpeg from GitHub releases via the API, and `act` doesn‚Äôt have a token, so it still errors even though ffmpeg is installed. `NEXT_STEPS.md` now reflects this.

Files touched:
- `.dockerignore`
- `.github/workflows/vhs.yml`
- `NEXT_STEPS.md`

Next options:
1) Provide a GitHub token to `act`: `make actions-vhs ACT_FLAGS="--bind -s GITHUB_TOKEN=YOUR_TOKEN"`
2) Skip local `act` and let GitHub Actions run the workflow on push to generate `assets/archlinux-kde.gif`
3) If you prefer, I can refactor the workflow to avoid `vhs-action` entirely and run VHS/ffmpeg directly in the job (no GitHub API call)

payload.text:
**Securing token usage in act commands**

I'm working on safely injecting the GitHub token into act runs without exposing it in command output or logs. I'm figuring out how to set environment variables and flags to suppress printing the token, considering using `make -s` to silence echoed commands while still passing the token securely.

**Securing token usage in act commands**

I'm working on safely injecting the GitHub token into act runs without exposing it in command output or logs. I'm figuring out how to set environment variables and flags to suppress printing the token, considering using `make -s` to silence echoed commands while still passing the token securely.

payload.text:
**Debugging token passing in act workflow**

I‚Äôm untangling why the action‚Äôs token input is empty when running with act. It looks like passing secrets via `-s GITHUB_TOKEN=...` isn‚Äôt making the token reach the action input, likely due to how act handles or maps secrets and environment variables. To work around potential reserved names or expression resolution issues, I‚Äôm considering renaming the secret (e.g., GH_TOKEN) and explicitly setting both the environment and action input to that, to ensure the token truly reaches the action. I'll test this approach next!

summary.text:
**Debugging token passing in act workflow**

I‚Äôm untangling why the action‚Äôs token input is empty when running with act. It looks like passing secrets via `-s GITHUB_TOKEN=...` isn‚Äôt making the token reach the action input, likely due to how act handles or maps secrets and environment variables. To work around potential reserved names or expression resolution issues, I‚Äôm considering renaming the secret (e.g., GH_TOKEN) and explicitly setting both the environment and action input to that, to ensure the token truly reaches the action. I'll test this approach next!

payload.name: apply_patch
payload.input:
*** Begin Patch
*** Update File: /home/deck/.github/workflows/vhs.yml
@@
       - name: Record demo with VHS
         uses: charmbracelet/vhs-action@v2
         with:
           tape: .github/vhs/archlinux-kde.tape
-          token: ${{ secrets.GITHUB_TOKEN }}
+          token: ${{ secrets.GH_TOKEN }}
*** End Patch

payload.text:
**Analyzing build failure and token issues**

I'm seeing build failures due to out-of-memory errors during the heavy Docker image build, preventing token usage or reaching the VHS action. To improve local runs with act, I‚Äôm considering skipping or slimming the build step when ACT is true, using prebuilt or lighter images, and ensuring the GH_TOKEN secret is correctly passed via job env and action inputs to resolve authentication issues as best as possible.

*** Update File: /home/deck/.github/workflows/vhs.yml

     env:

@@

         with:
           tape: .github/vhs/archlinux-kde.tape

+          token: ${{ env.GH_TOKEN }}
*** End Patch

payload.text:
**Evaluating build issues and proposing solutions**

I'm seeing that the local build with `act` keeps hitting out-of-memory errors, likely from the Docker build step. I'll explain the GH login worked and GH_TOKEN is set, but the build causes OOM with exit code 137. It might help to skip the build in `act` by adding a conditional or rely on a prebuilt image, or suggest running the workflow directly on GitHub Actions. I'll also mention cleaning Docker's resources and offer options for how to proceed, keeping tokens secure and noting the changes made in the workflow file.

summary.text:
**Evaluating build issues and proposing solutions**

I'm seeing that the local build with `act` keeps hitting out-of-memory errors, likely from the Docker build step. I'll explain the GH login worked and GH_TOKEN is set, but the build causes OOM with exit code 137. It might help to skip the build in `act` by adding a conditional or rely on a prebuilt image, or suggest running the workflow directly on GitHub Actions. I'll also mention cleaning Docker's resources and offer options for how to proceed, keeping tokens secure and noting the changes made in the workflow file.

payload.message:
`gh` is already logged in, and I wired the workflow to use a `GH_TOKEN` secret + env. I re‚Äëran `act` with that token, but the run now dies earlier during the Docker build with exit code 137 (OOM); it never reaches the VHS action, so we can‚Äôt confirm the token fix yet.

Change made:
- `/.github/workflows/vhs.yml` now uses `GH_TOKEN` via job env and `token: ${{ env.GH_TOKEN }}`.

How do you want to proceed?
1) Adjust the workflow to skip the heavy image build when running under `act` (or use a lighter Dockerfile), then re‚Äërun locally.
2) Push and let GitHub Actions run the workflow (no `act`), since it has more memory.
3) Try to reduce local Docker memory pressure (prune containers/images, lower build concurrency) and rerun `act`.

RUN pacman -Syu --noconfirm \
    && pacman -S --noconfirm \
        plasma-desktop \
        plasma-workspace \
        konsole \
        git \
        sudo \
        which \
        ttf-dejavu \
    && pacman -Scc --noconfirm

RUN useradd -m -G wheel -s /bin/bash deck \
    && echo "%wheel ALL=(ALL) NOPASSWD: ALL" > /etc/sudoers.d/wheel

COPY . /home/deck/deck0_dotfiles
RUN chown -R deck:deck /home/deck/deck0_dotfiles

USER deck
WORKDIR /home/deck/deck0_dotfiles
EOF

cat <<'EOF' > /home/deck/.github/vhs/archlinux-kde.tape
Output assets/archlinux-kde.gif
Set Width 1200
Set Height 675
Set FontSize 18
Set Padding 24

Type "docker run --rm deck0:ci bash -lc 'echo \"== OS ==\"; cat /etc/os-release; echo; echo \"== HOME ==\"; pwd; ls -la; echo; echo \"== KDE ==\"; pacman -Q plasma-desktop | head -n 1'"
Enter
Sleep 3s
EOF

name: VHS

on:

    paths:
      - ".github/workflows/vhs.yml"
      - ".github/vhs/archlinux-kde.tape"
      - "Dockerfile.archlinux"
      - "README.md"
      - "assets/**"
  workflow_dispatch:

permissions:
  contents: write

jobs:
  record:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - name: Checkout
        uses: actions/checkout@v4

      - name: Set up Buildx
        uses: docker/setup-buildx-action@v3

      - name: Build Arch Linux KDE image (cached)
        uses: docker/build-push-action@v5
        with:
          context: .
          file: Dockerfile.archlinux
          load: true
          tags: deck0:ci
          cache-from: type=gha
          cache-to: type=gha,mode=max

      - name: Record demo with VHS
        uses: charmbracelet/vhs-action@v2
        with:
          tape: .github/vhs/archlinux-kde.tape

      - name: Commit updated GIF
        uses: stefanzweifel/git-auto-commit-action@v5
        with:
          commit_message: "Update VHS recording"
          file_pattern: assets/archlinux-kde.gif
EOF

cat <<'EOF' > /home/deck/assets/.gitkeep
EOF

name: VHS

on:
  push:
    paths:
      - ".github/workflows/vhs.yml"
      - ".github/vhs/archlinux-kde.tape"
      - "Dockerfile.archlinux"
      - "README.md"
      - "assets/**"
  workflow_dispatch:

permissions:
  contents: write

jobs:
  record:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    env:
      RUNNER_TOOL_CACHE: /opt/hostedtoolcache
      AGENT_TOOLSDIRECTORY: /opt/hostedtoolcache
      GH_TOKEN: ${{ secrets.GH_TOKEN }}
    steps:
      - name: Checkout
        uses: actions/checkout@v4

      - name: Set up Buildx
        uses: docker/setup-buildx-action@v3

      - name: Build Arch Linux KDE image (cached)
        uses: docker/build-push-action@v5
        with:
          context: .
          file: Dockerfile.archlinux
          load: true
          tags: deck0:ci
          cache-from: type=gha
          cache-to: type=gha,mode=max

      - name: Seed ffmpeg cache for vhs-action
        run: |
          sudo apt-get update
          sudo apt-get install -y ffmpeg
          cache_dir="${RUNNER_TOOL_CACHE:-/opt/hostedtoolcache}"
          mkdir -p "${cache_dir}/ffmpeg/latest/x64/bin"
          ln -sf "$(command -v ffmpeg)" "${cache_dir}/ffmpeg/latest/x64/bin/ffmpeg"
          touch "${cache_dir}/ffmpeg/latest/x64.complete"

      - name: Record demo with VHS
        uses: charmbracelet/vhs-action@v2
        with:
          tape: .github/vhs/archlinux-kde.tape
          token: ${{ env.GH_TOKEN }}

      - name: Commit updated GIF
        uses: stefanzweifel/git-auto-commit-action@v5
        with:
          commit_message: "Update VHS recording"
          file_pattern: assets/archlinux-kde.gif

payload.message:
Adjusted the workflow to use ACT-specific inputs and a lightweight Dockerfile, pruned Docker to reduce local memory pressure, and pushed the updates so GitHub Actions can run the full workflow. The local `act` run should now be lighter; GitHub Actions should still build the full KDE image and generate the GIF.

Details:
- Added ACT-specific tape and Dockerfile so local `act` builds are smaller and use a different tape when `ACT=true` in `.github/workflows/vhs.yml`.
- Added the ACT tape and Dockerfile to the repo and allowed them in `.dockerignore` to keep build context small.
- Updated next steps to reflect the ACT token flow in `NEXT_STEPS.md`.
- Ran `docker system prune -f` (reclaimed ~10.47GB) and `docker builder prune -f`.

Files updated:
- `.github/workflows/vhs.yml`
- `.github/vhs/archlinux-kde.act.tape`
- `Dockerfile.archlinux.act`
- `.dockerignore`
- `NEXT_STEPS.md`

Next steps:
1) Wait for GitHub Actions to complete the VHS workflow and auto-commit `assets/archlinux-kde.gif`.
2) If you want to try locally again: `GH_TOKEN=$(gh auth token) make actions-vhs ACT_FLAGS="--bind -s GH_TOKEN=$GH_TOKEN"`.
3) Check `git status` and push if the GIF is committed locally.

Output:
# Next Steps

## Current state
- GitHub Actions/VHS workflow added; `.actrc` maps `ubuntu-latest`.
- `act` installed to `/home/deck/.local/bin/act`.
- `make actions-list` and `make actions-test` completed successfully.
- Added `.dockerignore` to keep build context small for the Docker image.
- `make actions-vhs` now builds the image but fails in `charmbracelet/vhs-action`: `Failed to install ffmpeg`.
- Workflow now seeds ffmpeg via `apt` and sets tool-cache envs, but the action still tries to download ffmpeg via GitHub API and fails under `act`.
- Added ACT-specific VHS inputs and a lightweight `Dockerfile.archlinux.act` to reduce local build pressure.
- `git push` to `origin main` succeeded.

## What to do next
1) Re-run `make actions-vhs` with a GitHub token for `act`, e.g.:
   - `GH_TOKEN=$(gh auth token) make actions-vhs ACT_FLAGS="--bind -s GH_TOKEN=$GH_TOKEN"`
2) If the local run still fails, rely on GitHub Actions for the recording.
3) If the GIF was generated/committed locally, check `git status` and push if needed.
4) Build and run the mock Proxmox container: `make mock-proxmox-build` then `make mock-proxmox-run`.
5) Run discovery against the mock SSH endpoint: `CHECK_HOSTS="root@localhost" SSH_OPTS="-p 2222" make discovery-full`.
6) If using MicroK8s, deploy the mock manifests and port-forward SSH as described in `mock/proxmox/README.md`.

## Testing and packaging (next steps)
- Testing: run the CI workflow `Proxmox Mock CI` after the next push to validate discovery against the local container mock.
- Testing: ensure the smoke test script passes locally (`scripts/mock-proxmox-smoke.sh`).
- Packaging: confirm the GHCR publish step succeeds on `main` and update tags as needed.
- Packaging: add a versioned release tag and a changelog entry when the mock image is published.

## Notes
- The VHS workflow will generate `assets/archlinux-kde.gif` and auto-commit it via GitHub Actions.

name: Proxmox Mock CI

on:
  push:
    paths:
      - "mock/proxmox/**"
      - "scripts/mock-proxmox-*.sh"
      - "Makefile"
      - "README.md"
      - "discovery/**"
      - ".github/workflows/proxmox-mock-ci.yml"
  workflow_dispatch:

permissions:
  contents: read
  packages: write

jobs:
  smoke-test:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - name: Checkout
        uses: actions/checkout@v4
        with:
          submodules: recursive

      - name: Build mock image
        run: make mock-proxmox-build

      - name: Run mock container
        run: make mock-proxmox-run

      - name: Run discovery against mock
        run: |
          CHECK_HOSTS="root@localhost" \
          SSH_OPTS="-p 2222 -i $HOME/.local/share/proxmox-mock/id_ed25519 -o StrictHostKeyChecking=no -o UserKnownHostsFile=/dev/null" \
          make discovery-full

      - name: Smoke test outputs
        run: scripts/mock-proxmox-smoke.sh

  publish-image:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    needs: smoke-test
    if: github.ref == 'refs/heads/main'
    steps:
      - name: Checkout
        uses: actions/checkout@v4

      - name: Set up QEMU
        uses: docker/setup-qemu-action@v3

      - name: Set up Buildx
        uses: docker/setup-buildx-action@v3

      - name: Login to GHCR
        uses: docker/login-action@v3
        with:
          registry: ghcr.io
          username: ${{ github.actor }}
          password: ${{ secrets.GITHUB_TOKEN }}

      - name: Build and push
        uses: docker/build-push-action@v5
        with:
          context: mock/proxmox
          push: true
          tags: |
            ghcr.io/realagiorganization/proxmox-mock:latest
            ghcr.io/realagiorganization/proxmox-mock:${{ github.sha }}

payload.text:
**Setting up local test running and mocking**

I'm working out how to enable local runs with act for all test actions in the repo, especially proxmox-mock-ci and thinkpadkali1dotfiles-discovery. This involves tweaking the Makefile, adding act-friendly tapes, handling submodules without SSH keys, and adding conditionals so checkout steps adapt based on whether ACT is running. I want to ensure submodules are correctly initialized locally and avoid failures from missing secrets by bypassing SSH keys during act runs. This will set up consistent local mocking for tests without hitting real hosts.
